page.title: 04ECOLOGY
page.content: This area of heathland with bracken, gorse & heather with encroaching birch and pine trees has a 50-60cms annual rainfall. The acid sand drains freely. There are many birds such as nightjars redstarts and linnets. Plantlife inc- ludes Harebells, Eyebright and Heath Pansies. Lizards are frequently seen. Grayling, Greenhairstreak, Gatekeeper and Silver Studded Blue butterflies occur. Coniferous forest plantations shelter Fallow, Muntjac & Roe dee & red and grey squirrels. A conserva- tion area along a stream is to be pre- served.There are Noctule, Pipistrelle and Longeared Bats, and Woodlarks and Tree Pipits. Farmland has mixed copses and replanted oak and sweet chestnut along a field. Rabbits, pheasants and French partridge feed. Many more species of insects, mammals, plants and birds feed here.
